tit.e: Daimyo (territorial lords) in the sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan
Daimyo (territorial lords) in the sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan
Sengoku Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period)
tit.cmt: 用語統一リストより訂正しました。

sen.j: 戦国大名（せんごくだいみょう）は、日本の戦国時代 (日本)に数郡から数カ国規模の領域を一元的に支配した大名を指す。
sen.e: A daimyo in the sengoku period indicates the daimyo who unified and controlled a territory of several counties to several provinces in the sengoku period in Japan.
A daimyo in the sengoku period indicates a daimyo who unified and controlled a territory of several counties to several provinces during the sengoku period in Japan.
The term sengoku daimyo refers to a daimyo who exercised unitary control over several districts or provinces during Japan's sengoku (warring states) period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 室町時代の守護大名と比べると、戦国大名は、中央権力と一線を画して領国の集権化を図った。
sen.e: Compared with shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) in the Muromachi period, daimyo in the sengoku period centralized the control of its territories, being not under the influence of the central government power.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Compared with shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) in the Muromachi period, daimyo in the sengoku period centralized control of territories, which were not under the influence of the central government.

Compared with shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) in the Muromachi period, daimyo in the sengoku period centralized control of territories, which were not under the influence of the central government.

sen.j: 特に被官・家臣の統制を強化し、知行高に応じて軍役を課す貫高制を確立した。
sen.e: In particular, the latter daimyo strengthened control of hikan (low-level bureaucrats) and vassals, and established the kandaka sei that imposed military duty based on chigyo daka (a stipend in terms of rice production of the fief).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In particular, the latter daimyo strengthened control of hikan (low-level bureaucrats) and vassals, and established the kandaka sei that imposed military duty based on chigyo daka (a stipend in terms of rice production of the fief).

In particular, sengoku daimyo strengthened their control over hikan (low-level bureaucrats) and kashin (vassals), and established the kandakasei system, a system for imposing military duties in return for chigyo daka (a stipend based on a fief's rice production).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 独自に被官・家臣間、領民間の争いを調停する分国法を制定するものもあった。
sen.e: Some daimyo in the period established bunkokuho (the laws to be enforced in their own territories) to mediate disputes between hikan and vassals or among residents in their territories.
Some daimyo in the period established bunkokuho (the laws to be enforced in their own territories) to mediate disputes between hikan and vassals or among residents in their territories.
Some daimyo in the period established bunkokuho (the laws to be enforced in their own territories) to mediate disputes between hikan and vassals or among residents in their territories.

sen.j: このような戦国大名による独自性の高い強固な領国支配体制を大名領国制という。
sen.e: The highly independent and solid territory control system employed by daimyo in the sengoku period is called the daimyo-ryogoku system.
The highly independent and solid territory control system employed by daimyo in the sengoku period is called the daimyo-ryogoku system.
The highly independent and solid territory control system employed by daimyo in the sengoku period is called the daimyo-ryogoku system.

sen.j: これは守護大名の守護領国制がより集権性を高めて発展した支配形態とされる。
sen.e: It is said that the control style of this system was reached by increasing the level of the central control in the shugo-ryogoku system (the system in which a shugo controlled a province).
It is said that the control style of this system was reached by increasing the level of central control in the shugo-ryogoku system (the system in which a shugo controlled a province).
It is said that the control style of this system was reached by increasing the level of central control in the shugo-ryogoku system (the system in which a shugo controlled a province).

sen.j: 戦国大名は、支配の正統性を確立し、近隣大名を凌駕するために、幕府から守護への補任を受ける者が多かった。
sen.e: Many daimyo in the sengoku period were appointed to shugo by the bakufu to establish their own legitimacy so as to surpass their adjacent daimyo.
Many daimyo in the sengoku period were appointed to shugo by the bakufu to establish their own legitimacy so as to surpass adjacent daimyo.
Many daimyo in the sengoku period were appointed to shugo by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to establish their own legitimacy so as to surpass adjacent daimyo.
sen.cmt: 幕府の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: このことから戦国大名を戦国期守護という概念で理解する見解もある。
sen.e: From this fact, there is the opinion according to which daimyo in the sengoku period were considered shugo in the sengoku period.
From this fact, there is an opinion that daimyo in the sengoku period were considered shugo in the sengoku period.
Based on this, some people view sengoku daimyo as being sengoku-period shugo.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 一方、支配正統性の確立・近隣への優越という動機に基づいて、朝廷へ多額の貢納を行う見返りに 官位（武家官位）を獲得する戦国大名も多数存在した。
sen.e: On the other hand, many daimyo made lots of donation to the imperial court, based on the motive to establish the legitimacy of control so as to surpass the adjacent daimyo, and secured an official court title (buke-kani (official court titles for samurai) in return for the donations.

On the other hand, many daimyo made generous donations to the imperial court, as a means to establish legitimate control and surpass adjacent daimyo, securing an official court title (buke-kani (official court titles for samurai) in return for the donations.

In order to legitimize their control or gain an advantage over neighboring daimyo, many sengoku daimyo gave substantial donations to the Imperial Court in return for an official title (these titles reserved for samurai were known as buke kani).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Imperial Court大文字にしました。

sen.j: これにより衰亡寸前だった天皇の権威が再認識されることとなった。
sen.e: In this situation, the authority of Emperor, having been on the brink of ruin, became to be recognized again.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In this situation, the authority of Emperor, having been on the brink of ruin, came to be recognized again.
In this situation, the authority of Emperor, having been on the brink of ruin, came to be recognized again.

sen.j: 天皇は戦国末期～安土桃山時代の天下統一に少なからぬ役割を果たした。
sen.e: Then Emperor played not a little role in unifying the control of the entire nation in around the end of the sengoku period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Emperor at the time played no small role in unifying the entire nation around the end of the sengoku period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
The Emperor at the time played no small role in unifying the entire nation around the end of the sengoku period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.j: 戦国大名による領国化が著しく進展し、国内は分権的な様相を呈していた。
sen.e: Daimyo in the sengoku period advanced the level of the independent control of their territories significantly, rather decentralizing control of the nation.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Daimyo in the sengoku period advanced the level of independent control over their territories significantly, which decentralized control of the nation.
Daimyo in the sengoku period advanced the level of independent control over their territories significantly, which decentralized control of the nation.

sen.j: しかし、織田信長・豊臣秀吉の天下統一により一転して集権化へと向かい、戦国大名の独立性は薄まっていく。
sen.e: However, the unification of the nation by Nobunaga ODA and Hideypshi TOYOTOMI switched the situation towards centralizing control of the nation, making the activities of daimyo in the sengou period less independent.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the unification of the nation by Nobunaga ODA and Hideypshi TOYOTOMI brough the nation under centralized control, making activities by sengoku period daimyo less independent.
However, the unification of the nation by Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI brought the nation under centralized control, making activities by sengoku period daimyo less independent.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: こうした流れの中で、戦国大名は幕藩体制下の近世大名へと移行していった。
sen.e: In such a trend, daimyo in the sengou period changed into daimyo in the early-modern times under the shogunate system.
Under these circumstances, daimyo in the sengoku period changed into daimyo known during the early-modern times under the shogunate system.
Under these circumstances, sengoku daimyo made the transition to being early-modern daimyo in the shogunate system.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 戦国大名の出自の概要は以下の通りである。
sen.e: The origins of daimyo in the sengoku period are roughly as follows:
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The origins of daimyo in the sengoku period are roughly as follows:
The origins of daimyo in the sengoku period are roughly as follows:

sen.j: 佐竹氏・今川氏・武田氏・土岐氏・六角氏・大内氏・大友氏・島津氏らのように守護大名に出自した例、朝倉氏・尼子氏・長尾氏・三好氏・長宗我部氏・神保氏・波多野氏・織田氏・松永氏らのように守護代やその臣・陪臣に出自した例が多数を占めたが、毛利氏・田村氏・龍造寺氏・筒井氏らのように国人層や宗教勢力に出自した例も多かった。
sen.e: Many of them are shugo daimyo (for examples, those of the Satake clan, Imagawa clan, Takeda clan, Toki clan, Rokkaku clan, Ouchi clan, Otomo clan and Shimazu clan) or shugodai (deputy of shugo, provincial constable), their vassals or baishin (indirect vassals) (for examples, those of Asakura clan, Amago clan, Nagao clan, Miyoshi clan, Chosogabe clan, Jinbo clan, Hatano clan, Oda clan and Matsunaga clan), but there also were many daimyo who came from the kokujin (local samurai) class or religious backbones (for examples, the Mori clan, Tamura clan, Ryuzoji clan and Tsutsui clan).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Many of them were shugo daimyo (for examples, those of the Satake clan, Imagawa clan, Takeda clan, Toki clan, Rokkaku clan, Ouchi clan, Otomo clan and Shimazu clan) or shugodai (deputy of shugo, provincial constable), their vassals or baishin (indirect vassals) (for examples, those of Asakura clan, Amago clan, Nagao clan, Miyoshi clan, Chosogabe clan, Jinbo clan, Hatano clan, Oda clan and Matsunaga clan), but there also were many daimyo who came from the kokujin (local samurai) class or religious backbones (for examples, the Mori clan, Tamura clan, Ryuzoji clan and Tsutsui clan).

Many sengoku daimyo were originally shugo daimyo (such as the Satake, Inagawa, Takeda, Toki, Rokkaku, Ouchi, Otomo and Shimazu clans), while many others were originally shugodai (shugo deputies) or their vassals/retainers (such as the Asakura, Amago, Nagao, Miyoshi, Chosokabe, Jinbo, Hatano, Oda and Mastunaga clans). There were also many who were originally local lords or religious powers (such as the Mori, Tamura, Ryozoji and Tsutsui clans).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その他、後北条氏・斎藤氏のように幕府吏僚・浪人に出自する者も少なからずいた。
sen.e: In addition, not a few daimyo in the sengoku period came from bakufu officers or ronin（masterless samurai）, such as the Gohojo clan or Saito clan.
In addition, not a few daimyo in the sengoku period came from bakufu officers or ronin（masterless samurai）, such as the Gohojo clan or Saito clan.
Additionally, there were also many sengoku daimyo who were originally bakufu officers or ronin (masterless samurai), such as the Gohojo and Saito clans).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、守護と管領を兼ねていた上杉氏や北畠氏のように国司から、土佐一条氏のように公家から戦国大名化した例もあった。
sen.e: Furthermore, some such daimyo came from kokushi, like the Uesugi clan and Kitabatake clan that held both shugo and kanrei (shogunal deputy) positions, and some daimyo in the sengoku period, such as the Tosaichijo clan, came from court royals.

Furthermore, some such daimyo came from kokushi, like the Uesugi clan and Kitabatake clan that held both shugo and kanrei (shogunal deputy) positions, and some daimyo in the sengoku period, such as the Tosaichijo clan, came from court royals.

There were some who were originally kokushi (like the Uesugi or Kitabatake clans, who held both shugo and kanrei (shogunal deputy) positions) and others who were originally court royals (such as the Tosaichijo clan).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 戦国大名は、領国内に一円的な支配を及ぼした。
sen.e: A daimyo in the sengoku period controlled his territory entirely.
A daimyo in the sengoku period was completely in control of his territory.
A daimyo in the sengoku period was completely in control of his territory.

sen.j: この領国は高い独立性を有しており、地域国家と呼びうる実態を持っていた。
sen.e: Controlled highly independently, each of these territories had a reality that it might be called a regional nation.
Being highly independent, each of these territories could be called a regional nation.
Being highly independent, each of these territories could be called a regional nation.

sen.j: 戦国大名は、国人・被官層を家臣として組織化し、自らの本拠地周辺に集住させて城下町を形成した。
sen.e: A daimyo in the sengoku period organized persons in the kokujin (local samurai) or hikan (low-level bureaucrats) class as his vassals and made them live around his base place to form a castle town.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A daimyo in the sengoku period organized persons in the kokujin (local samurai) or hikan (low-level bureaucrats) class as his vassals and made them live around his base place to form a castle town.
A daimyo in the sengoku period organized persons in the kokujin (local samurai) or hikan (low-level bureaucrats) class as his vassals and made them live around his base place to form a castle town.

sen.j: このようにして国人・被官層と土地・民衆との間の支配関係を解消もしくは弱体化しようと図った。
sen.e: In this way, the daimyo tried to dissolve the controlling-controlled relationship between persons in the kokuji or hikan class and the general public or to diminish the extent of the relationship.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In this way, the daimyo tried to dissolve the controlling-controlled relationship between persons in the kokuji or hikan class and the general public or to diminish the extent of the relationship.
In this way, the daimyo dissolved or weakened the relations of power between the kokujin/hikan class and the land/general populace.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 在地社会に対しては、在地社会の安全を確保する見返りに軍役を課すとともに、検地を実施して新たな租税収取体系を構築した。
sen.e: For the society in his territory, a daimyo imposed military duty on his people in return for making the society secure, and also checked the land status to establish a new tax-collecting system.

For the society in his territory, a daimyo imposed military duties on his people in return for securing the safety of the soceity, and also checked the land status to establish a new tax-collecting system.
As well as imposing military duties on the local populace in exchange for maintaining order, the daimyo also established a new taxation system after carrying out a land survey.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、国人・被官層及び在地社会における紛争を調停する基準として分国法を制定する者もいた。
sen.e: Some daimyo established bunkokuho (the laws to be enforced in their own territories) as a base for mediating disputes among persons in the kokujin and hikan classes and other disputes in their territories.

Some daimyo established bunkokuho (the laws to be enforced in their own territories) as a base for mediating disputes among persons in the kokujin and hikan classes and other disputes in their territories.
Some daimyo established bunkokuho as a base for mediating disputes among persons in the kokujin and hikan classes and other disputes in their territories.
sen.cmt: 既出のため、分国法の説明を削除しました。

sen.j: こうした戦国大名による地域国家内の支配体制を大名領国制という。
sen.e: This territory control system employed by daimyo in the sengoku period is called the daimyo-ryogoku system.
This territory control system employed by daimyo in the sengoku period is called the daimyo-ryogoku system.
This territory control system employed by daimyo in the sengoku period is called the daimyo-ryogoku system.

sen.j: ただし、戦国大名は、地域国家内において必ずしも超越的な存在ではなかった。
sen.e: However, the authority of daimyo in the sengoku period was not always unlimited.
However, the authority of daimyo in the sengoku period was not always unlimited.
However, the authority of daimyo in the sengoku period was not always unlimited.

sen.j: 戦国大名の権力基盤は、家臣として組織化された国人・被官層だった。
sen.e: Power of daimyo in the sengoku period was based on the persons in the kokujinn or hikann class who were organized as his vassals.
Power of daimyo in the sengoku period was based on the persons in the kokujinn or hikann class who were organized as his vassals.
Power of daimyo in the sengoku period was based on the persons in the kokujin or hikan class who were organized as his vassals.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 室町時代中期頃から日本社会に広がった一揆は、国人・被官層にも浸透した。
sen.e: The uprisings that spread around the Japanese society from around the middle of the Muromachi period infiltrated into the kokujinn and hikan classes as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The uprisings that spread around in Japanese society around the middle of the Muromachi period infiltrated the kokujinn and hikan classes as well.
The uprisings that spread across Japanese society during the Muromachi period also spread to the kokujin and hikan classes.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そのため国人・被官層は自らの利権を共同で確保していくため、国人一揆といった同盟関係を構築していた。
sen.e: Therefore, persons in the kokujinn and hikan classes established an alliance of something like a kokujin uprising to keep their rights.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, persons in the kokujinn and hikan classes established an alliance to form a kokujin uprising in order to retain their rights.
Therefore, persons in the kokujin and hikan classes established an alliance to form a kokujin uprising in order to retain their rights.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 戦国大名は国人・被官層が結成した一揆関係に支えられて存立していたのである。
sen.e: The existence of daimyo in the sengoku period was supported by the uprising-based relationships formed by persons in the kokujin and hikan classes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The existence of daimyo in the sengoku period was supported by the uprising-based relationships formed by persons in the kokujin and hikan classes.
The existence of daimyo in the sengoku period was supported by the uprising-based relationships formed by persons in the kokujin and hikan classes.

sen.j: 国人・被官層の権益を守る能力のない戦国大名は排除されることもあり、こうした事例は下克上と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Therefore, some of the daimyo in the sengoku period who could not keep rights of the kokujin and hikan classes were removed, and when such a situation occurred, it was called an example of gekokujo (the situation where inferiors overthrew their superiors).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, some of the daimyo in the sengoku period who could not retain the rights of the kokujin and hikan classes were removed, and when such a situation occurred, it was called an example of gekokujo (the situation where inferiors overthrew their superiors).

Some daimyo who couldn't protect the interests of the kokujin/hikan classes were removed from power, a situation which was known as gekokujo (people of lower standing overthrowing their social superiors).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。
